title: Is China more capitalist than the US? - Quora

response.answer_text: They both operate under the global capitalist market and thus have variations of capitalism for their economic system. The United States economy is dominated by privately-owned enterprises and features very little national-level economic planning or direction (which is not the same thing as regulation); the Chinese economy has a large state sector and an active role for state-directed activity through state owned enterprises and through use of the financial system to direct economic development. The United States economy is best described as a “standard” relatively free-market capitalism, whereas China’s economy is best described as state capitalism. Ideologically the People’s Republic of China is socialist, meaning its official aim is the development of a socialist economy and society. Officially the Chinese economic system is called a “socialist market economy” but it is hard to consider it socialist while stock markets exist, widespread private ownership of industry exists alongside state ownership, wage labor remains the dominant and often sole source of income, and the state sector keeps its profits as retained earnings. Only time will tell if China will actually be able to make a successful transition to some form of socialism in the future.
